contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Charles Marie René Leconte de Lisle | image = Leconte Blanquer.JPG | imagesize = 200px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1818|10|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Saint-Paul, Réunion]], France | death_date = {{death date and age|1894|7|17|1818|10|22|df=y}} | death_place = Voisins (near Louveciennes), France | occupation = Poet | nationality = France | period = 1846–1894 | subject = | movement = [[Parnassian poets]] | notableworks = | influences = [[Horace]], [[François de Malherbe]], [[Jean Baptiste Racine]], [[Victor Hugo]], [[Alphonse de Lamartine]], [[Alfred de Vigny]], [[Hughes Felicité Robert de Lamennais]], [[André de Chénier]], [[Évariste de Parny]], [[Louis Ménard]] | influenced = [[Stéphane Mallarmé]], [[Sully Prudhomme]], [[Léon Dierx]], [[François Coppée]], [[Catulle Mendès]], [[José María de Heredia]], [[Antoni Lange]], [[Anatole France]], [[Rainer Maria Rilke]], [[Arthur Rimbaud]], [[Paul Verlaine]], [[Stefan George]], [[Adam Asnyk]], [[Jerzy Żuławski]], [[Leopold Staff]], [[Auguste Villiers de l'Isle-Adam]], [[Jean Richepin]], [[Rubén Darío]], [[Felicjan Faleński]] | signature = }} '''Charles Marie René Leconte de Lisle''' ({{IPA-fr|ʃaʁl maʁi ʁəne ləkɔ̃t də lil}}) (22 October 1818 – 17 July 1894) was a French poet of the [[Parnassian poets|Parnassian]] movement. ==Biography== Leconte de Lisle was born on the island of [[Réunion]]. His father, an army surgeon, who brought him up with great severity, sent him to travel in the [[East Indies]] with a view to preparing him for a commercial life. After this voyage he went to [[Rennes]] to complete his education, studying especially Greek, Italian and history. He returned once or twice to Réunion, but in 1846 settled definitely in Paris. His first volume, ''La Venus de Milo'', attracted to him a number of friends many of whom were passionately devoted to classical literature. In 1873 he was made assistant librarian at the [[Luxembourg Palace]]; in 1886 he was elected to the [[Académie française]] in succession to [[Victor Hugo]]. His ''Poèmes antiques'' appeared in 1852; ''Poèmes et poésies'' in 1854; ''Le Chemin de la croix'' in 1859; the ''Poèmes barbares'', in their first form, in 1862; ''Les Érinnyes'', a tragedy after the Greek model, in 1872; for which [[incidental music]] was provided by [[Jules Massenet]] (which included the "Invocation" for cello and orchestra, an arrangement of his famous "Élégie"); the ''Poèmes tragiques'' in 1884; ''L'Apollonide'', another classical tragedy, in 1888; and two posthumous volumes, ''Derniers poèmes'' in 1899, and ''Premières poésies et lettres intimes'' in 1902. In addition to his original work in verse, he published a series of prose translations of [[Theocritus]], [[Homer]], [[Hesiod]], [[Aeschylus]], [[Sophocles]], [[Euripides]], [[Horace]]. He died at Voisins, near [[Louveciennes]], in the department [[Yvelines]]. [[File:Leconte de Lisle.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Leconte de Lisle]] ==References== *[[J.
